This game is quite interesting, and I enjoyed the time I put into it. But, there are some flaws. Some levels are particularly long and boring, just mazes that you need to find your way through with no real challenge. Enemies are incredibly easy to abuse and rarely introduce any challenge. The only time enemies are a problem is when there is water involved, since it makes you both loud and slow.   

Also, nothing is ever really explained. I was hoping that when I completed the game I would learn something more about who I was, who the enemies were, why I was doing what I was doing or even, ultimately, what I was doing at all. But the game offers no explanations for any of this. Instead, it offers a "light world" variant of the same levels with extra enemies in. Which, as I've already established, adds practically no difficulty.  I cannot be bothered playing the same 40 levels a second time just to see if anything is explained after that, but I doubt it is.

38744488.review:
[h1]Reasons why the game can be enjoyable[/h1]
[i]Dark Echo[/i] is an atmospheric game where you'll be guided by the echo of your footsteps to find a way out. It's visually simple, but the color scheme is enough to make you feel like you're actually in a dark room. The screams when you die and the weird sounds enemies make are enough to create a little bit of tension on us.

The game is cheap and it can be a distraction when you have nothing else to do. It also has achievements and trading cards, so completionists (like me) might enjoy it.

[h1]Reasons why I can't say I like it[/h1]
I found its premise to be deceiving. I have read, on both store page and news, that the game turned sound into gameplay, which is not true. Playing on mute or without headphones makes absolutely no difference. I was expecting something where I could play with my eyes closed and be guided by my ears, but all I had to do was look at the lines on the ground.

Its puzzles aren't exactly puzzles. Everything you need to do is walk around, find some switches (I've always found them before I even knew there was a closed door), hide from enemies or run from them. The most thinking you'll need is to decide when to walk and when to sneak.

It doesn't live up to its horror categorization. You don't even get to know what the enemies are. It's not a bad game, I was just... expecting something else.

38516184.review:
For being such a short game, it's worth playing it for it's price.

The sound design is spot-on, from the echoing footsteps to the sound of water droplets, giving the game it's perfect claustrophobic atmosphere. It's level design reinforcing this atmosphere even further with narrow hallways, small rooms, and even deadly little bridges. It's not even a horror game, but instead more of a puzzle game. If you think it's more a horror one then go ahead, we won't judge!

The game's mechanic itself about revealing your surrounding through sounds makes for some interesting puzzles and challenges, although it becomes a bit repetitive on later levels. It still remains fun nonetheless!

Overall, this is one solid and fun game to play. It may be short, but it's still a blast trying to sneak past the monsters and solving puzzles!

38276407.review:
Creative, unique, repetitive and boring...

I was really looking forward to playing this one, since I enjoy exploring unqiue games that introduced new gaming mechanics.  Unfortunately, the idea itself is the best part.

The game is visually interesting, even though it is very simplistic.  That, along side the sound design creates an immersive experience, unfortunately that experience is not very exciting, nor interesting.

A game like this really has a great opportunity to slowly introduce new and more interesting/challenging gaming mechanics, but this one just does more of the same, over and over.  I was bored after the first few levels and the rest became tedious...Another of those games you just cannot wait until it is over :(

Good game design does not mean "filler" levels...This is a case of wanting the game to end, since there is nothing to look forward to, but there were way too many repetitive levels implemented.  It really feels just like simple mazes that you can only see from the reflected sound waves, just not very fun.


ACHIEVEMENTS:  Simply play the game...There are 15 hidden treasures to collect as well.

35259710.review:
Oyunda karanlıkta hapsolmuş karakterimizi sadece sesleri kullanarak karanlıktan çıkarmaya ve ışığa ulaştırmaya çalışıyoruz. Oyun tamamen ses üzerine kurulu. Ses bizim hem gözümüz hem kalkanımız hem de ölüm sebebimiz durumunda. Oyunda iki dünya mevcut. Işığa ulaştığımız vakit ikinci dünya yani ışığın hakim olduğu dünya karşımıza çıkıyor ve bu sefer de ışıktan kaçmaya çabalıyoruz. Toplam 40-40 olmak üzere 80 bölüm var ve oynayışı çok zevkli bir oyun.

+ Yepyeni bir oynayış mekaniği var.
+ Gerçekten başta bir gerilim hissetiriyor.
+ Eğlenceli, akıcı, devamlı oynama isteği yaratıyor.
+ Fiyatı böyle bir oyun için çok ucuz.
+ Steam kart ve başarım mevcut.

Oyun ile ilgili söyleyebileceğim kötü şeyler şunlar:
- Başta hissettirdiği zorluk ve gerilim hissi oynadıkça kayboluyor. Heleki 15. bölümden sonra gayet evinizdeymiş gibi gezebiliyor ve rahatça bölümleri geçebiliyorsunuz.
- Oyun bana kalırsa bir puzzle oyunu değil, çünkü çözülecek (1-2 bölüm dışında) puzzle yok. Tek amacınız karanlıktan ışığa ilerlemek ve önünüze çıkan engelleri atlatmak, çözmek değil. Bence zorluğu pekte yok.

33201770.review:
This is actually really nice, not that scary, but nice concept. Scanner Sombre in 2D. The screenshots don't do it justice, the moving sound rays convey the space around the character precisely and underscore the actual audio, steps and ambient noise.

It's a bit curious that all the obstacles and monsters don't themselves have any sound while not in motion, but that's probably a gameplay element. Still, when standing *right next* to one, I'd expect some sort of audio cue regardless.

The audio sometimes isn't super helpful in determining the direction to go and in some of the levels I felt more lost than anything (and in those cases an extra sprint action would be nice to - if I feel safe enough to make more noise, why not? It'd save a little bit of time when exploring). A few of the puzzles need very precise control and that's something where I'd also like to see some mouse control, if not even a target indicator.

All in all recommended.

32714527.review:
真っ黒な中を音の反響による線を頼りに進んでいくアドベンチャーゲーム。
といってもほとんどパズルのようなもので、ゴリ押しは通用する場面も少ないしそもそもそんな事する必要があまりない。

箱○コン対応で、多分こっちのほうがやりやすい。
チュートリアルをクリアしないと使えないが、Aで手を叩いて広範囲にエコーを出す（強弱あり）。Xで忍び足。Yで石を投げる。
敵は赤い塊で移動時に音を出して接近してくる。壁は意味をなさず、壁越しでもエコーが届いてしまえばまっすぐこっちへ向かってくる。
逆にエコーが届かなければ例えば曲がり角ならエコーの線が角の向こう側に届かないこともあり、接近してこない。
まぁさらに逆で存在に気づけないほうが辛いが。
石はこのゲームにおける神アイテムで、石を無音で投げ、その方向に敵を誘導することができる。
自分は忍び足で反対側を通り抜けるだけでいい。忍び足はほんの少しエコー線が出るけど敵には感知されない。
一応、バグなのかわからないけど石が投げられなくなる事がある。
このゲームに石の数の概念があるかは不明だが、長期的に1ステージをやってるのならそこにも注意。
まぁ長期的にやっている時点で迷って詰み状態なので、ステージをやり直して右壁の法則でもやりながら進む方がいい。
慣れてくると、手を叩いて敵を確認したら石を適当な方向にポンポン投げてじゃまにならないところに誘導し先にすすめる。
エコーで青く表示されるところは水辺で、忍び足でもそこそこ大きな音を出してしまう。
が、これも立ち止まればエコーは出ず立ち止まって石を投げて敵を誘導し続ければゴリ押しで進むこともできる。
1面だけこれが反転することがあるのでそこだけ注意。

飽きてきたら手をリズム良く鳴らしながら進んでみるといい。楽しい。それだけ。

32682839.review:
真·盲人模拟器

很有创意的小游戏~ 由自己或环境制造的声波来探索世界~ 声波碰到障碍物会反射并衰减~ 根据声波判断终点位置~ 每一关都有自己独特的地方~ 难度也比较亲民~
游戏的环境声效也很有特色~ 虽然看不见，但是能听到角色大概是在什么样的材质上走路~ 还有一些地方会产生环境声波，例如滴水、风声、门声，甚至… 陌生人的~ （也大概能猜到那些危险的地方是什么样的..）

WSAD移动 （行走时会制造声波）
SHIFT键静走 （制造的声波会衰减）
空格键拍手（静止不动也可以制造声波）

以下是含有轻微剧透的攻略：
[spoiler]
第一关·盲眼 基础移动教学~ 
第二关·逃脱 教会你空格键的作用~
第三关·死亡 产生红色的声波的地方（以下简称“危险”）不能碰~ 会死掉~
第四关·追捕 一开始会有一个能制造红色声波的东西（以下简称“敌人”）主动追你~
第五关·捕猎 会有一些敌人藏在暗处，如果被你反馈的声波碰到则会跑来追你.. 不过同时只会被一个敌人追~ 这关稍微有点难度~推荐用SHIFT潜行键慢慢走~
第六关·冷静 有点像是教学关卡.. 新出现了会发出黄色声波的东西（以下简称“机关”），碰到以后会触发一个未知的机关，这个机关会打开某处被堵住的路~ 并且会发出声波~ 有引到附近的敌人的风险~
第七关·陌生人 这关的机关很多.. 有些门里面有危险，要小心一点.. 不过这关没有敌人，可以不用SHIFT大胆走~ 结尾出现了一个真·陌生人向出口跑去..
第八关·诡计 会有许多机关，和许多碰到机关放出的敌人.. 在这一关里，每碰到一个机关都会封死你的去路并在另一个方向重新给你一条路，要快速判断方向而不被敌人追到~
第九关·迷宫 这关吓死个人咧.. 在迷宫里走会在一些拐角突然出现被困在墙里的敌人，虽然不会被追，但还是好吓人啊 - -..
第十关·宁静 啊咧..? _(:з」∠)_ 这关才是真正的SHIFT键教学关.. 不过前面也有关卡能用呀w
第十一关·潜行 会有环境声波告诉你大概方向，按住SHIFT慢慢走就是了~
第十二关·花招 同上.. 只是地形复杂了一些~
第十三关·目击者 一开始会碰到一位陌生人被一个超大的怪物追到终点逃掉（告诉了你终点的位置），但是超大的怪物还留在终点附近.. 潜行慢慢走过去就好.. 如果大怪物碰到了你的声波会分散出一堆小怪物来…… (话说为啥陌生人可以跑步啊..qwq 嘛也许不是盲人吧..)
第十四关·连锁 左右各一个机关，每个碰到都会释放出怪物，直到这关我才发现… 当怪物未接收到你的声波一小段时间后，便不会继续来追你.. 但不会消失，会停留在原地，小心不要招惹到他了…
第十五关·哗啦 新出现蓝色声波地方（以下简称“水”），在水里会降低移动速度，并且SHIFT潜行下也会制造大量声波~  

先写到这里好了.. _(:з」∠)_晚点再更w
[/spoiler]

31658002.review: This is a unique and fun experience. It's pitchblack, but you can see sound waves bouncing off stuff to navigate and find the exit. You can use sound to distract monsters too. The sound waves are super smooth and satisfying to watch, and that honestly makes the game; it's just mesmerising. Great creepy atmosphere. You never get to see where you are or what is going on, but it's not good. You step in nasty things and hear others meeting bad ends in the mazes of the levels. You really feel like you are there. 31634327.review:
"Version longue d’un jeu Ludum Dare, Dark Echo vous propose de marcher dans le noir à travers 80 niveaux plus ou moins longs. En appuyant sur la touche Espace, vous générez du bruit et pouvez ainsi apercevoir les murs devant vous. Les ennemis sont en ondes rouges, les interrupteurs en ondes jaunes, etc. Le but étant évidemment de parvenir à la fin des niveaux sans se perdre ni se faire manger tout cru.

Cette simulation de survie dans le noir, tout en 2D, est de plus intelligentes. Générant le son à la perfection, elle propose une montée en puissance, en difficulté, en adrénaline, de grande qualité. Quand les dix premiers niveaux sont des plus simples, les cinquante à venir se compliquent de plus en plus. La suite est encore plus intelligente et le jeu réserve quelques surprises à ceux qui y accrocheront. Pour son prix, il est largement conseillable !"

Vous pouvez lire davantage d'articles sur Http://www.gamesidestory.com

30281905.review:
Интересная задумка. Нужная атмосфера неизвестности. Но чего-то этой игре не достаёт. 

Уровни не то что однообразны, но становятся скучными быстро. В смысле, противники могут подбегают к вам, если вы сделали шаг не туда. Но если вы сделаете на шифте хотя бы шаг в сторону, то вас не заденет. И в принципе так всегда можно обходить монстров. Кто-то стоит на пути? Прыгаешь, существо подходит к тебе, а ты тихонько отходишь в сторону. Кидаешь камешек подальше от места, куда тебе нужно добраться и быстрро добегаешь туда. И хоть уровни разные, такую тактику приходится вытворять много раз.

Есть уровни не только с монстрами, и это радует. Но некоторые уровни совсем непонятные. Их сложно проходить потому что стены движутся после каждого шага. И никто даже не объяснит, как это проходить.

Есть уровни с обвалами. И вот когда персонаж получает способность кидать камешки, никто не объясняет, что расчистить завал камешек тоже может помочь. Хотя да, это я сам не догадался.
Очень интересно то, что вы не знаете, что происходит. Довольно интересно, как выглядят эти монстры. И как этот монстр-босс выглядит вообще. Насколько они огромные? И кто ещё кроме нас там по подземельям бегал? То, что вы не видите, отлично раскрывает игру.

Игра хорошая. Годнота. Но она не для тех, кто хочет экшена. Медленный геймплей и куча смертей. Хотя иногда придётся побегать от монстров, которые бегут прямо за вами, дышут в спину, это добавляет каплю разнообразия Но это случается редко, если вы не сорвиголова.

Всё же эту игру я хвалю. Спорный вопрос, покупать ли игру, или нет, но она и стоит недорого. Для разнообразия попробуйте.

Um ótimo jogo. A jogabilidade é única e incrivelmente intensa as vezes. Os gráficos, como dá pra ver, são minimalistas, mas nisso são bem executados. 26070298.review:
For its price, the game is worth it.
The first 20-25 levels are alright. They present an interesting challenge that you don't find in any other game. It didn't make me fevereshly excited, but I was enjoying it nonetheless. 
After that the puzzles become cheap. It is impossible to finish some levels without luck or dying few times, and I couldn't be bothered to continue playing. What's especially damning, is that in the first levels the game teaches you to be thoughtful and strategic, while later levels present challenges in the style of action games like Hotline Miami, which require luck or trial and error. I don't know if it's the only case when the game punishes you for what it tought you, but I suspect there's more of that later.
Maybe it's too much to pay any money for it, considering the amount of enjoyable content is similar to that of a good flash game, but I don't think it's a problem. If you have some spare pennies, the game is worth it.

25725529.review:
This game can be more unnearving then the simplistic design may lead you to believe. Its not a horror that will make you jump out of your skin, its more a feeling of dread. We are visual creatures, so not being able to see whats around you properly, not knowing whats around you until its (potentially) too late. It also leaves what these demonic sounds following you up to interpritation. 

The sound design is excellent, as it should be with a game based around it. You can tell when you're stepping through water, through blood, when there is death near you, the crumbling walls and the shifting stones, its all told through sound and what the sound waves shown tell you about your world. 

Its a sort of stealth adventure game with the puzzle ellements getting stronger as you go along. By the end of the game you are sort of able to lead and manipulate the creatures which is what really drives it away from its initial stealthy feel. However this does not put the game on easy mode and no matter where you are in the game, the crunching of bones and death scream of your character is always jarring when you get something wrong. 

All in all, if this sounds remotely appealing to you, especially with the low cost, I would say take the chance on it. Its a great little game.

25109468.review:
In a saturated market where video games are released daily you’ll see a fair share of experimental games that try to be something different and unique but fail in one way or another, but this game is the exception. One of the best aspects is that it remembers about being a game first, while being complimented by everything else. The idea is unique and something I’ve personally have not seen before, and is not pretentious about it.

The visuals are an excellent style choice and leave plenty for imagination, which makes for a unique and terrifying experience. You don’t know what is going on around you or where you are, sometimes you don’t know what is going to happen next, but that’s part of what makes this game great and tense. It’s pretty to see all those visuals slowly change in front of you by your actions, although you won’t always be able to appreciate them for too long because you’ll be in danger constantly. But they can make for pretty screenshots and wallpapers if you experiment enough.

There is no music, only small ambient sounds and the sounds made by your character and other entities. However it doesn't need any music to begin with, for it would detract from the focus, but I assure you the sound design will end up stuck in your head and you'll be remembering the sounds for quite a while. Some sounds were a little too hauting for me I must admit.

Overall is not a complicated game, in fact is not a hard game either, it can be a little frustrating at times, however I appreciate its focus on simplicity, especially because simplicity well done is a rarity. The mechanics are not hard to understand and it’s very well designed from start to finish. And really, there is not much to say; it is what it is and does a fine job, but I enjoy it for what it is and for delivering an unerving experience. It might be short, but for the small price is absolutely worth it and one of the most unique games I've seen in a while. Is even better experienced on a dark room with headphones!

24568271.review:
I started watching Markiplier play this game, but I quickly stopped, because it looked so cool that I wanted to experience it for myself first. I just bought it, and played for 2.5 hours straight. I love it! (And it's certainly much longer than I expected it to be — 2.5 hours and I'm not even halfway done!)

If you really think about it, Dark Echo is actually a fairly standard puzzle/escape/psychological thriller game: You navigate, you evade monsters, you avoid death traps, and sometimes you have to activate switches (represented by yellow patches). But the sound mechanic, in which you navigate by visualized sound waves, changes everything. Instead of giving you a puzzle to solve in each level, it makes navigation a puzzle in itself. And it's a puzzle that gets progressively more complicated and challenging as new elements and mechanics are introduced and combined with each other, requiring increasing amounts of cleverness to overcome.

A bonus: The fact that you are effectively walking around in pitch darkness, and often threatened by monsters and traps, makes this something of a horror game as well. Your blindness makes the experience tense and constantly charged with the threat of the unknown. And the inscrutability of your environment presents an ontological mystery: You don't know who you are, where you are, how you got there, or what the world wants from you. (I doubt any of these questions will be answered by the game, but a sense of mystery always makes horror/thriller games even more fun.)

Edit: I just played for another half an hour. When I first wrote this, I was at level 37 or 38. At Level 40, I made an important discovery, which is that the next 40 levels are a "mirror" of the first 40. Your player character finally escapes the darkness he was trapped in, stepping out into the light, where you can hear birds chirping. And then you're taken to a level select screen that's the same as the first one, except that black and white are inverted. I've played a few of these "light" levels so far, and they are largely the same as their "dark" counterparts (including their names), except that black and white are inverted, in some ways they seem to be tougher, I'm pretty sure there are more monsters, and it seems that the monsters can now move through walls. I had to stop playing only a few levels in because I was mentally drained. I'm a bit disappointed that the last half of the game seems to be just a "tougher" mirror of the first — especially since I'm not sure that it's tougher in a good way. But I haven't finished yet, and I don't know if there might be any surprises in store.

완전히 가려진 시야 안에서 소리만을 의지해 출구를 찾아간다는 컨셉은 상당히 신선했다.
검은 (혹은 하얀)배경과 발자국과 소리를 표현해 주는 선, 적을 표현하는 빨간색과 물을 표현하는 파란색만으로도 이렇게 흥미롭고 재밌는 게임을 만들 수 있다는 것이 놀랍다.
게임의 메인 테마는 소리인데 그래픽이 거의 없는 대신 소리에 상당히 신경을 썼다. 배경음악도 없지만 효과음이 뛰어나다. 발소리, 물 소리, 개구리, 함정의 소리, 적들의 움직이는 소리가 플레이어의 귀를 때리면서 긴장감과 몰입감을 극대화 시켜 준다고 해야할까. 적을 공격하는 대신 조용히 걷거나 돌(이라고 생각되는 무언가)을 던져 적의 주의를 끌며 출구를 향해 가고 점프(라고 생각되는 무언가)로 전체적인 맵을 파악하는 등 소리로 할 수 있는 것들은 대부분 구현해 냈다고 생각한다. 

총 80개의 스테이지 중 40개는 하드모드와 같은 개념이지만 3300원의 값은 차고 넘치게 하는 게임이다. 가격도 매우 저렴하니 반드시 해보길 추천.

23974037.review:
Great first half, tedious second half.

The game is beautiful in its initial visual simplicity and concept, and gradually adds depth and mechanics so as not to leave you overwhelmed. In the first 30 levels, only one felt frustrating, and like I beat it improperly / not the way it was meant to, which left me overall very satisfied.

However, once the first half is done, you are given the option to replay all the levels, but with additional enemies added and retaining access to all previous mechanics. Initially intriguing, halfway through it just ended up feeling unfun again due to having to constantly create distractions for every step forward you want to take.

Buy it cheap, enjoy the Dark World, then stop playing.

23607557.review:
The concept of this game is wonderful, and the first twenty or so levels are very enjoyable. Learning how to use sound to both navigate and avoid the monsters is fun while not excessively challenging. Then however you get to the later levels.

Moving platforms, that you cannot see. Sudden forced movement that you can't explain. Almost impossibly fast reactions required to avoid death many times when you don't know what to expect, and when the game manipulates what you think you've learned by making that same behavior kill you.

To a certain extent this could define any particularly challenging game, but I feel Dark Echo crosses the line from challenging to just down right frustrating because the game seems to require you to play through the level and die several times to learn exactly how to move because there is no way to know what you should do on your first, second, or even third try. But after that you've seen all the traps, and know exactly what to do to avoid them because you've DIED to each of them before.

I have been enjoying this game, and I will finish it, but I was forced to rage quit when a level seemed clearly designed to require several attempts to learn the exact pattern of the traps so you could navigate them, which seems like a poor design choice. That said however, if you don't mind a little potentially rage quit inducing challenges, I'd highly recommend this game none the less.

23606058.review:
Dark Echo is a game does a lot with very little. It takes one core mechanic - in this case, echolocation - and builds everything off of that, which is something I honestly wish more games did. It makes for a very tightly-woven experience where the gameplay, environment and story (what little story there is, at least) are all woven together seamlessly in one immersive experience. Granted, this game lacks visuals entirely, outside of the visual representation of echolocation, but that's also part of the genius of it. The echolocation system is intuitive and grows on you quickly to the point of feeling second-nature, plus it makes the player use the mechanics given to them to not only solve the puzzles and beat the levels, but also explore the levels and make sense of their environment. Not only that, but it has the players doing these things simultaneously. The game gives you no context as to where you are, what you're doing or why you're doing it (I guess you could say you're going into the experience "blind" . . . I'm sorry), so you just have to use context clues to figure things out. These are usually things that would be completely mundane in a game with visuals, but figuring out what things are purely based on your sound-wave-line-things and the sound effects in the game makes even the simplest environmental details intriguing. And as you play the game, you will get much better at "seeing" with the echolocation mechanic. Like I said earlier, the single mechanic which the entire game is based on works perfectly, is extremely intuitive and most importantly, is a lot of fun to use. It's also really fun to look at in its own weird way, which is good considering it's the only thing you can see throughout the entire game. 
I also want to touch on the "horror" aspect of this game, since that's one of the tags for the game. This game is very tense purely based on its mechanic, making it one of the purest tension-fueled experiences there is. The focus on making the game feel tense and atmospheric was a good choice, seeing as the fear of the unknown works perfectly with the "blindness" of the player." The horror elements are not at all elaborate (as this game is built on simplicity) and won't provide a traditional horror game experience by any means, so I'm not sure I'd call this a "scary" game, but it is surprisingly thrilling. You will be running from monsters and avoiding deadly traps as you traverse mazes, and the death sounds are a bit gruesome. Still, this game is not for the horror audience. If you don't like scary games, I'd still give this game a try, although be warned it is tense. If you're okay with scary games, there's no reason not to try it. If you're looking specifically for a scary game, this is not the one for you.
Overall, this is a great game. I wrote this review mostly to commend it on its tight and simple game design. This game knows what it does, and it does it extremely well. This is something I wish more games developers would think about more when making games. "What's the core of this game, and how can we tie everything in the game to that core?" Doing this 100% with every game simply wouldn't be possible, but keeping this idea in mind when designing a game I think could help create a tighter, more immersive experience.

23347934.review:
Dark Echo is certainly an excellent take on the idea of sound-based perceptionin a video game, though there are some negative aspects i would like to cover later. I would recommend that you buy it, play it, and get a refund, for reasons you'll see later.
  First, though, the game is mostly an excellent experience. Suspense is created very effectively, as well as some mild horror. The game's mechanics are very polished and nice, with it's slightly randomized sound wave direction, so that no walk will be exactly the same; the sneak mechanice's effectiveness in water could be adjusted for more realism, but i understand that it's wave length is so expansive for the sake of the suspense and challenge; the enemies' speed is just enough to provide great suspense, and the large enemy is certainly a great fear that the game always gives you a chance to avoid (or rather, run from). The simple style of the game provides a nice ambiance, so that if you stop making sound for even a few seconds, you will be lost until you make sound again, likely putting you in danger.
  Now on to negative points. First off, the game is NOT worth $2.99, since there is simply not enought content, in my opinion, to be priced that high. $1.49 maximum. The game is inconsistent in the later levels(30-40 mainly),in that it "throw's away" the machanics it has taught you from the beginning. one level leaves you stranded in a widely expansive empty map, following sounds of dripping water just beyond your view. no other place in the game [i]requires[/i] you to listen for direction or guidance. another level leaves you in a room where you must obeserve the pattern of moving landscape to find an opening to stop the motion at a specific time which will allow you to progress (harder than it sounds). My biggest point, though, is level 37: "lost", in which you are placed in a large landscape of rough-walled caves where you must [i]walk around blindly until you randomly find the exit, with other paths leading you to dead ends with enemies[/i].
  The game also has a "light mode", which is simply a negative print of the game with enemies added to nearly every room, faster enemy movement, turned rooms, or some rooms' layout changed. The game's achievements also consist of "beat normal mode", "beat hard mode", and "collect every secret". The game is good, but mostly due to the extravagant price and lack of both general content and replay value, i'll put it this way:
  I should have my refund soon.

I like the originality and tone of the game.  I like how simple it is without being easy.  It's a great time killer when you're waiting around for something.  Overall, I'd highly recommend this game.

But, there are a few things that I'd have liked to be different:
1. I would say the game was a little too short.
2. It could've used a little bit more variety with enemies.  For example, maybe one that doesn't kill you, but can see you without you moving and can alert others.  Or, maybe one that pushes you rather than kills you.
3. The difficulty sort of "caps out" long before you reach the end.  The game continues to introduce interesting concepts, but it doesn't really get harder.  To be fair, there isn't a whole lot the developers could do about this without making the game tedious or impossibly hard.

But don't let those complains deter you.  This is still a great game

22619596.review:
"Dark Echo" jest logiczną grą z minimalistyczną grafiką i bardzo pomysłową mechaniką. Celem jest odnalezienie wyjścia z każdego z kilkudziesięciu poziomów. Poruszamy się jednak w całkowitej ciemności, a jedyną pomocą są rozchodzące się fale dźwiękowe - czyli coś na kształt echolokacji. Im głośniej "tupiemy" tym fale rozchodzą się dalej i możemy odkryć większy zarys pomieszczenia, w którym się znajdujemy. Musimy jednak uważać - zbyt głośne zachowanie może zwabić tajemnicze monstra, z którymi kontakt kończy się szybką i gwałtowną śmiercią. Ciche poruszanie też nie jest bezpieczne - można wdepnąć w pułapkę, którą odkryliśmy zbyt późno.

Gra ma świetny klimat budowany głównie dźwiękiem (najlepiej grać w słuchawkach), a skromna grafika znakomicie współgra z mechaniką i grywalnością. Mam jednak poczucie lekko niewykorzystanego potencjału. Dość szybko odkrywamy wszystkie mechanizmy i po kolejne plansze nie wnoszą już nic nowego. Można było umieścić nieco więcej niespodzianek w tych ciemnych labiryntach.

Ale grę oczywiście polecam. Z pewnością warto się zapoznać - szczególnie za tak przystępną cenę.
Moja ocena: 7/10

Dark Echo je originální logická hra, ve které ovládáte slepou postavu pomocí vizualizovaného zvuku. Musíte projít čtyřicet relativně krátkých úrovní, zorientovat se v prostoru, vyhnat se pastem a odlákat nepřátele. Mechaniky jsou opravdu jednoduché, ale relativně zábavné a hra rychle ubíhá a nenutí vás zbytečně opakovat podobná řešení.
Po dohrání všech úrovní se odemkne druhá část hry - bílý svět. Zde máte projít všechny úrovně ještě jednou, jen se zvýšenou obtížností: přibylo pastí i nepřátel, A tady nastává problém. Nejde ani tak o to, že hrajete ty to, co už jste jednou prošli, to je spíš výhoda. Jde o místy přestřelenou, neférovou obtížnost, která z relativně zábavné hříčky dělá frustrující otravnost. Některé finální levely jsem procházel na desítky pokusů a věřte, že to pak už zábava moc nebyla.

Dám palec nahoru především kvůli nízké ceně. I když dohrajete jen první (temný) svět, hra za těch pár korun stojí.

游戏本身：独特的游戏方式与界面让玩够了3A大作的人会感到耳目一新。通过回声来定位，结合了迷宫，探险，解密，动作操作等等因素，而且上手非常容易，可以自行摸索出许多小技巧。游戏画风色彩对比强烈却不让人觉得浮夸，通过黑、白、红、蓝、黄这些最基本的色调塑造了一个独立完整的特别世界。加上满分的音效渲染烘托出恰到好处的恐怖氛围，投掷石块的声音、怪物追击的声音、入水行走的声音、开锁的声音、踩在干燥地面上的声音.......让人感觉身临其境。关卡的难度循序渐进，到了后期会出现难关。游戏代入感十足，寻找收集隐藏宝藏探索未知的过程；白世界的后半段受虐的快感以及取得成就的征服感对于本人这种带有抖M性格的来说实在太美妙了。本游戏虽然只有三个成就，但是成就成色十足（具有一定的挑战性），是本人这种全成就党最爱的类型。——9/10
游戏感想：真正可怕的不是无边无尽的黑暗也不是灼目的白炽，而是至始至终孤独的脚步。
技巧干货：关于困扰很多玩家的收集隐藏宝藏的成就我只留下几个神秘数字，你们自己去体会。黑06、13、14、19、20、22、.24、26、27、28、29、31、32、33、39。

21114180.review:
Dark Echo has a great novel concept and a nice art style. Unfortunately, it does not fulfill its promise. I liked the beginning a lot, but becomes boring and tedious later on. I played the dark levels on Android and some of the white levels on PC, so I can compare both versions.

There are 3 main mechanics in the game (tapping, sneaking, throwing rocks). They are interesting early on, but no other concept is introduced later on, and there are no new mechanics introduced in the later levels (maybe except moving objects). The game seems to be a half-finished, with so many interested things that could have been introduced in the game, but weren't.

The number of levels is low. There are 40 dark levels, which you can finished in a couple of hours, and 40 white levels, which are the same levels with many more (and bigger and faster) enemies, and a very uncomfortable full-white background. There's not much motivation to play the white levels. Also, one wonders why there aren't more unique levels than 40. Given that designing new levels seems extremely easy, their current number feels more like a demo than a regular game.

The controls are unfortunately very poorly implemented. On touch devices, it's very hard to sneak, and sometimes you perform a regular step instead of sneaking, which means instadeath in later (white) levels. Imprecise controls on touch devices was a reason why I switched to PC version for later levels. On the other hand, on touch devices you can very easily throw rocks into arbitrary direction, and it's very easy to precisely position your enemy. Mind-bogglingly, you can't do that on PC. Even though it would be very obvious to use mouse cursor to throw rocks, you can't, and you can only throw to 8 basic directions using the keyboard. Also, you always need to face the direction you're throwing into, so you can't distract an enemy by throwing a rock to the side when running away, as it would be natural. With gamepad, you can throw to arbitrary directions, but as is usual with a gamepad stick, aiming is hard. So while PC version makes it easier to move, it makes it harder to aim compared to touch devices. In none of the versions you can control your character [b]well[/b]. Controls were my number 1 frustration when playing later levels. The ideal controls seem so obvious - left mouse click to walk, shift to sneak, space to tap, right mouse click to throw to the exact direction. Yet it is not there.

Hopefully someone will use this concept and make a great with it, with more interesting levels, more enemy types, more interactive and environment objects (I can imagine e.g. terrain elevation changing sound waves reflection), better controls, more fun.

21094911.review:
Dark Echo is a minimalistic exploration game. You are shrouded in darkness (or, for the second half of the game, in blinding light), and the only way for you to navigate through the levels is the echos of your footsteps (represented by colored lines which radiate out from where you’re standing). You have the ability to stomp your foot (making louder echoes), walk silently (to avoid alerting enemies to your presence), and throw stones (to make echoes in a remote location to lure enemies away).

The game is very simple; there are only a handful of mechanics. There are red enemies who move towards the last sound they were in range of earing, there are pits of water which slow you down and which make a lot of sound to move through, there are red areas that killed you if you moved into them, there were walls that would collapse when you made a loud sound (opening an area but also attracting enemies), and there were moving blocks which pushed you around.

Mostly, the game worked fairly decently; you are introduced to all the games’ mechanics gradually over the first half of the game, and navigate through a series of increasingly-difficult levels which force you to combine the mechanics in increasingly interesting ways.

While the game was mostly fairly solid, the moving blocks mechanic was probably the most frustrating; while it only appears in a handful of levels, the fact that the pushes are so difficult to see ahead of time is kind of frustrating. Eventually you figure out how they work (for a while, I just thought they were sloped areas that I was skidding down), but at times it felt like the game broke its own rules, such as one level where you had to navigate up little ramps that felt like they actually were sloped areas on the sides of the room.

Mostly, though, the game played very fairly, and even the frustrating levels were mostly quite short. After beating the game, you could hunt back through for treasures, or play through the “light” versions of the levels, where additional enemies were added in to make you play more carefully (as well as the layouts of some of the levels being changed to make them more difficult).

That said, the game is nothing super special; the gameplay isn’t really amazing, but it is decent enough. Ultimately, this is a sort of time-waster game – the sort of thing you’d play while chatting to someone or doing something else, sporadically playing it. It was originally a mobile game, and I suspect it is better suited to that platform simply because of its “play in short bursts” nature.

Still, it is okay, and if you’re looking for something to do between doing other things, it isn’t a bad choice, and goes to show that just because you don’t spend a whole lot on graphics doesn’t mean you can’t make a visually striking game. Just dont' expect it to be anything more than a distraction.

21037165.review:
[b]February 7, 2016[/b]
Dark Echo is a mobile game with unique minimal graphics, which some people view artistically. In actuality, the game is a top-down casual adventure game with sound built into the graphics. Yes, it's unique, but the game quickly runs out of material and becomes irritating to finish. The low price helps, but it's not a game I'll likely remember.

The core gameplay is to reach the exit, avoiding red traps and pushing yellow plates to open walls. Detecting objects requires sounds, so most of the time you will be sending out foot pings to map out rooms. The real gameplay opens up when enemies are introduced, and sounds become a risk of detection. In the best moments, Dark Echo is about outmaneuvering enemies and feeling smart about your moves.

In the worst moments, Dark Echo is about trial & error memorization of traps and enemies, since the optimal playstyle is to make no noise. Issues come up when the game throws in more enemies and more water, forcing you to drag groups further out of the way so you'll have more time to move. Enemy detection also shows issues, as detection is dependent on sound lines hitting enemies. Sound lines may be pretty consistent, but it would make more sense to be doppler waves for consistency. Rock tosses will generally miss at medium range, unless the rock hits a wall to amplify. Too much time is spent spamming rocks to move enemies just right, and waiting on the slow death animation.

Although the game has 80 levels, half of them are repeats with added difficulty. The survival horror concepts are lost with the flood of identical enemies and repeated deaths. The puzzle elements are minimal switches, and no real mental challenge outside memorization. The lack of tension and challenges leave the game feeling like a grind to finish, despite being short. It would take closer to 5+ hours to complete, and I left the game idle overnight. I suppose the game isn't too expensive, but I wasn't impressed or pleased by the second half. Sadly it's another artsy game that says nothing and puts style over substance.

20902298.review:
Wow, this has to be one of the most innovative minimalist games I've played in a long time.  Most indie games these days seem to try to take an existing game as an archetype, strip out all the fluff, and leave the core mechanic, whatever that may be.  By and large, this makes for a great game, because it's hard to invent something truly new, but slightly easier to see a AAA game fail, read the reviews, and then re-hash it taking all the negative comments into consideration.   

Dark Echo, on the other hand, creates a whole new mechanic, and makes a wonderful game out of it.

In a funny way (and bear with me here), Dark Echo's "special sauce" (that genre-holotype-defining quality of the first game in a string of variants) reminds me a little of Amnesia, Dark Descent... The main mechanic of that game was that if you can see the monster, it can see you, so you have to tiptoe about and hide away in corners, turning your back to monsters so they can't see you.  If you loved that juxaposition, you'll love Dark Echo.   In this game, rather than light (sight), it's sound that allows you to see the monsters, but as soon as you 'see' them via your echoes, they 'see' you too!  So it's a constant game of making just enough noise to 'see' by, but not too much!   A lovely little balancing act that can take a few deaths to get right!

In another funny way, it reminds me a little of Ico (again, bear with me).  After all, I hear you say "Whereas Ico was a visual extravaganza, this is a minimalist line drawing!".   I'm referring to the atmosphere, really.  The wonderful sounds, the echoes, the vastness of some of the 'spaces', the lack of explanations, the constantly running away from stuff.  It's got a great little mythos going for it.  I wouldn't be surprised if someone didn't write a little fan fiction for it...  

So, what is it?  In it's essence, it's a puzzler where you have to navigate a top-down 'level' full of tricks, traps and 'monsters', to reach the 'safe zone'.   So far, so simple.  The hard part is the aforementioned visibility mechanic and managing it so that you can navigate around without being caught.

The game comes in two flavours: Dark and Light.  The light levels are (by and large) the same as the dark levels, but with a few added monsters and/or water.   In a funny way, the light levels feel like the 'completion' of the dark levels, or possibly that the dark levels were a 'trial run' of the light levels.   Often water is placed at critical places to slow you down, and make lots of splashes for the bad guys to hear...  Sometimes the level's structure is adjusted ever-so-slightly to make you change your tactic on the second run-through.   Some of the levels are identical, but with a monster or two thrown in.  For most of the second half of the game, I felt that things were new-enough to merit finishing the game.  

So, as someone who doesn't have a lot of time any more to play games, I'm happy to say that Dark Echo ticked all my boxes: It's new, it's amusing, it's inventive, it's minimalist, and doesn't break its own rules all the time.  Everything's well laid out, sounds fantastic, and yes, wear headphones! It creeped me the heck out! :)

20727825.review:
I noticed that I've been far too kind to a lot of free-to-play artsy games recently, and I made a private promise that I'd go on a negative streak. I started with "You Have to Win the Game", and I suppose I might as well continue with Dark Echo.

Now, I'm not recommending Dark Echo because I think it's a bad game. Dark Echo is an incredibly unique game with a stealth system all-it's-own. I just personally don't like it. But if you think the points I bring up won't bother you, then by all means buy this game.

Dark Echo is a stealth/horror game built around the idea that you're blind and have to rely on sound to guide your way through what I think is a castle with a ton of enigmatic monsters living inside it. The mechanics are very unique. If you choose to move quietly to not disturb the monsters, you won't be able to see far ahead and predict incoming obstacles. However, if you choose to be loud and find out what's ahead, you might attract monsters who will eat you. But all this challenge and fright is pretty much diminished by the rocks. Once you get those all the levels that follow are an absolute piece of cake. 

Dark Echo is certainly a horror game. It plays well with what you see as well as what you don't see, and uses sound to amp up the atmosphere and tension. But without a story, context, or building challenge to the monsters I didn't find myself sweating with terror at the end. I felt relieved, sure, but I know if the game put a little more oomph! into it, Dark Echo could be so much better, and so much scarier. 

Again, if this sounds appealing to you, go nuts. Dark Echo is still an incredibly unique experience. But beyond the sometimes blandly simple levels and lack of story to really put things into context (and the added on padding where you simply play through all 40 levels again, but in the light), it just wasn't a game for me. But it might be the perfect game for someone else.

Overall I do like what I've played of this game so far and I could recommend it to anyone who may be considering getting it. Cheers! :)

20130066.review:
i played the original Ludum Dare version of this game several years ago and enjoyed it a lot, so it's very nice to see it become a full-fledged release.

as you might be able to infer, navigating using only sound and the visualizations it gives is a tense and foreboding experience. although there are occasionally things like the sound of water droplets to help give a better picture of your environment, most of the time you can only rely on your footsteps to see what is around you, not knowing if there's something deadly silently lurking around the corner waiting to pounce.

of course, since i actually like to mess around in horror games, one of my favorite things to do is lure baddies with a large stomp and then tiptoe a few feet away and watch them give up as soon as they reach the source. they lose interest immediately and it's kind of hilarious.

another little detail i enjoy is that there are different footstep noises; you might be walking on stone for a while but one corridor later you'll be walking on dirt or grass. it really adds a nice touch to each area, since you can kind of infer what your surroundings are even though you never actually see them.

overall this game is "Outta Sight" and if you don't believe me you should "See It For Yourself" because it's "A Hidden Gem" and it's pretty cheap too.

14年上过ios平台的月最佳游戏，相比移动触屏端的操作，pc端是使用键盘，灵活度偏低，例如扔石子只能8个45度夹角方向扔，如果要想得到游戏灵活的体验，可以尝试ios或Android平台，当然也可以把pc端当作一个难度加大版来进行游戏。
这是一款非常精致而又非常独特的迷宫类游戏，中文名叫：回声探路，顾名思义，就是要自己发出声音通过回声判断位置进而寻找正确路线走出迷宫。游戏的图像素材很简单：一对脚印，五种颜色，以及两种粗细的线条，就可以完成这一款游戏的制作，有时候游戏制作缺的不是美工不是画面，更多是灵活的思路。
游戏开始叫你建议戴耳机玩，的确是个不错的建议，游戏的音效挺逼真，听着声音配合自己想象力很好模拟场景，但是就是不要太大声了，很容易受惊吓。属于需要依靠自己想象而得到恐怖环境效果的游戏。游戏的声音真的恐怖吓人，但是对于爱好恐怖类游戏的人来说可能算是优点。
游戏分黑章白章两章，每章40关，元素不多，教程短而易懂，很好上手，所以我也没必要在评测上说怎么玩，剩下的就是要自己去理解身边的现象来进行行走。总之，游戏的可玩性挺高，发挥自己的想象力，带着各种具象化的声波，好好体验一下黑暗中行走的感觉吧~游戏相对于大多数游戏不贵，只要2.99刀，物美价廉，万圣节可能会打折~另外卡的价格好高，收集五套卡花费比两个游戏还贵（最后感谢一个好友送的这个礼物）
另外，成就党注意：虽然只有三个成就且前两个通关就得到，第三个收集的成就可能需要费很多时间，所以全成就难度还是有点大
个人给分：9.5/10
+++出色的创意
+++逼真的音效
+++关卡很丰富
++游戏高性价比
+教程简单易懂
-第二章画面有点刺眼，看久容易疲劳
-比起移动端灵活性低一点
---音效吓人

18479271.review:
[h1][i][b]Dark Echo[/b][/i] is an evocative piece of art with one of the most brilliant sound designs seen in videogame history. That uses [b]stealth[/b] and [b]survival horror[/b] conventions to materialize the fears living in our subconscious through abstract and geometrical shapes inspired by the paintings of [b]Rothko[/b][/h1]

[i][b]«It’s always night, or we wouldn’t need light»[/b][/i] - [h1][b]Theloniuos Monk[/b][/h1]

Do you remember the first time when you played [i]Super Mario Bros 3[/i]? And while you were running through a prolonged and almost infinite hill, pushing the jump button you realized that now Mario could fly. And then, you were amazed with this magic sense of discovery while you explore a vastness sea of pixelated clouds. Creating the magic illusion of exploring a new world in which every single element is full of novelty, an explosion of the senses.

Our gaming memories are full of this accomplished moments of realization. Like the first enemy that you glitch in [i]Axiom Verge[/i]. The first kiss you give in Yoshirou Kimura’s cult classic [i]Chulip[/i]. Or when you rewinded the time in [i]Braid[/i] to reach an unattainable floating plattform for the first time.

[i]Dark Echo[/i] has one of these memorable and most captivating single moments experienced in recent videogames. In the form of the first time that you keep pushed the action button, and releasing it you can see how an explosion of visible and corporeal sound waves helps to materialize a previously occult and cryptic hidden dimension. With a plethora of abstract and evocative geometrical forms dazzling our eyes with pure joy. An intense array of emotions are concentrated in this mere act of pushing a single button. As an expression of why the videogames are considered art.

In its first hours, this magic sense of realization never ceases. An absorbing sensation that creates an oppressive feeling in the player, while he’s surrounded by invisible menaces laying in the shadows. An universe where the most feared ghosts plaguing our subconscious are waiting for us surrounded by darkness. Waiting to become corporeal with the mere stimulus of a sound.

We can only figure the world that lies beneath [i]Dark Echo[/i] via the materialization of sounds, this fragmented instant of time when a a wave elongates making tangible a mysterious and almost cryptic alternative reality that lives isolated in a corner of our memories, close to our childhood traumas. Playing [i]Dark Echo[/i] is like doing a unconscious journey through our fears and hopes, only using our imagination in a synesthetic way, associating sounds and its geometrical effects with inner terrors. And all of these sound elements are augmented by one of the most cohesive artistic designs seen in a videogame, clearly influenced by the paintings of Rothko in its constant use of the black and red colors.

Its level structure is not so distant of a stealth game, where we need to generate geometrical forms thorough sounds to confuse our captors. With a perfect difficulty curve that adds new elements and functions at a very slow pace. The 20 first levels serves as a tutorial, and from 20 onwards, you should prepare to die a lot. It’s like an even more minimalist approach to the VR missions seen in the first [i]Metal Gear Solid[/i]. Also, [i]Dark Echo[/i] shows its smart design nature by using the name of each level as an evocative clue to resolve its main obstacle. A demonstration of the love and care that its creators have put in the development process. 

Maybe [i]Dark Echo[/i] can be seen as a small game. But it’s a game in which every single element has been created with an ambitious and creative approach. A short but extremely polished experience that tries to not saturate the player with irrelevant content. Over the years and with the consequent saturation of the gaming market, I appreciate games that really try to be small but memorable journeys. Significative creations in gaming history that we will never forget.

Note that [i]Dark Echo[/i] isn’t the first experiment created in the videogame medium to recreate the experience of being a blind person. Previously, the japanese punk videogame designer idol Kenji Eno created [i]Real Sound: Kaze no Regret[/i] for Sega Saturn. A game that was designed with blind people in mind, using only sounds and with not a single image. In his next game, Kenji Eno will use the sound as a design fundamental again, with the release of [i]Enemy Zero[/i]. A survival horror with invisible enemies, that only can be detected by using a sound radar. 

Sadly, Kenji Eno passed away in 2013. But I’m sure that if he lived today, he would become fascinated with [i]Dark Echo[/i].

17795006.review:
This experience will stay with you forever.

As the blurb suggests, Dark Echo sees you utilising sound to enable you to visualise your surroundings. The sounds you create ricochet around you in the form of coloured lines. You goal, naturally, is to escape the darkness, and escape whatever the hell is in it with you.

I found the gameplay enjoyable overall. The difficulty curve is just right - with a bit of persistence and some careful planning, navigating the darkness can be fun, sometimes scary, but achieveable for everyone. Controls consist of basic movement, throwing stones for decoys, clapping your hands (with various degrees of strength, depending how long you hold the button down for), and stealth. And you'll probably be using stealth quite a bit.

You have your white, regular soundwaves for normal surfaces, yellow for switches. But the real fun starts with blue and red soundwaves. Blue is for water, which is something you'll want to avoid on account of it being so noisy, and red you'll also want to avoid, on account of it being able to kill you at a touch. 

And oh my god, if you die. The first time I died I almost leapt a full metre out of my chair. The death scream is perfect. In fact, most all the sounds are done to perfection. From your echoing footsteps to the sound your hands clapping together, it is very well done. 

Dark Echo really is a worthy addition to any gamer's library. While it lacks a story of any sort, it does do everything else right, giving us a new take on fear, exploration and stealth. Even if it doesn't sound like fun to you (I don't imagine how this could be) get this game and give it a try. Price alone is reason enough.

I'd deifnitely recommend this game and, at £1.99, it's an absolute bargain.

It's easy to recommend this game to people who like puzzle games. It's surprisingly simple but effective mechanics, are used to their fullest; where it's not a matter of just rushing through a level, but in most cases you are using stealth. 17498130.review:
Well, I'm a bit stuck on level 29 right now, and given as how there are 80 levels to this game, I highly doubt I will be finishing it. However, conceptually, it is pretty cool, and in practice, the game mechanics work well. 

Basically, it is pitch black with the only light coming from sound, which bounces off the walls and objects, thus illuminating your path briefly. Also, your footprints leave a trail. Sadly, the sound also serves to attract an all consuming evil, in the form of red lights. Normal sound is represented by white light, doors (and I guess treaure although I'm not exactly certain how that works) is represented by yellow, and water (the bane of your existence in this game, lol) is blue. Somewhere around level 20, you find rocks which you can throw to distract the all consuming evil, which is especially handy when you also have to cross water (which also slows your movement). Each level basically ends by finding the exit "doorway" which explodes with white light when you step into it.  Oh...and you can also move with stealth, which reduces your sound radius and helps you to sneak through that pesky all consuming evil.

There are some other nuances so far, such as needing to use rocks to break through walls, and certain levels where you cant hide from the all consuming evil and simply have to run for it. The level I am on currently, you have to cross waterways which actually push you into the awaiting evil (I guess this is the waters current). 

The game does have full controller support, which is how I play it.

Anyway, I actually think this is a stellar game, and minimalistic perfection in what is essentially a unique puzzle game.

I give this game 8 muffled footsteps out of 10 with the remaining 2 betraying you to the all consuming evil, which I will simply dub as Shoggoth.

17272448.review:
Знаете, как снять хороший триллер, который будет держать зрителей в напряжении? Нет? Спросите у RAC7 Games - они точно знают.

Вы не найдете в этой игре сногсшибательной реалистичной графики - только собственные следы, угасающие фронты звуковых волн и красные всполохи на месте рычащих чудовищ. Вы не найдете здесь продуманных и построенных по всем законам жанра диалогов, берущих за душу, - только звук шагов, шум падающих капель, да жужжание мух над менее удачливыми предшественниками. Единственный текст, который может пролить свет на историю, - название глав. Другие люди (а люди ли?) - только быстрые шаги за стенкой и душераздирающий крик не слишком осторожных беглецов.

Но настоящий страх живет не там, где монстр выскакивает из-за угла и пугает просто неожиданностью. Настоящий страх живет в воображении, когда зритель сам додумывает те ужасы, которые трудно воссоздать на экране. А для этого нужна хорошая доля неопределенности и втянутости в происходящее на экране. С обоими пунктами игра справляется прекрасно. И если вы играли в эту игру и ни разу не задерживали дыхание, когда чудовище пробегало мимо вас, или не вздрагивали, когда после долгой погони большое нечто настигало вас и сжирало, расплескивая кровь по стенам, - вы маленький лгунишка :) замирали и вздрагивали

Стоило бы рассказать про сюжет, но рассказывать нечего. И потому, что его как бы нет, и потому, что он как бы есть, но состоит только из небольших намеков в событиях и названиях глав. Каждый придумывает свою историю, корректируя, если надо, с получением новых подсказок. Мне, например, представилось следующее: научный комплекс, где случайно-специально произошло нечто, что вырубило свет и выпустило на свободу кровожадных монстров; главный герой - представитель иного гуманоидного вида, т.к. прекрасно ориентируется на слух (почему не человек с хитрым оборудованием? Из-за первой белой главы - [spoiler]выйдя на свет он ослепнет[/spoiler]), но ходит на 2 ногах, умеет хлопать в ладоши и кидать камешки. Оружия там нет, поэтому полагаться приходится исключительно на собственную ловкость, скорость и сообразительность (в первую очередь на нее, так как монстры поражают своей глупостью - явно они появились не в результате естественного отбора).

Так мы плавно подошли к геймплею. В арсенале у нас способность по звуку оценивать окружающую обстановку (почти как летучие мыши). Звук можно производить шагами, хлопать в ладоши и кидать камешки (тогда источник звука будет в месте падения камня). Так мы видим препятствия, воду, ловушки, но у всего есть минусы - на шум сбегаются все чудовища, которые его слышат. Поэтому можно не только топать, как слон, но и аккуратно красться на цыпочках.

Собственно и всё. В общей сложности вас ждет 80 уровней, которые периодически заставляют остановиться и слегка пересмотреть свое мнение об игровом мире и тех приемах, которые нужны, чтобы выжить. Простая, но в своем роде гениальная идея. И учтите, что это не хоррор, а в первую очередь головоломка.

10 капель воды из 10.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=476597526

P.S. на черных уровнях спрятаны "сокровища", за нахождение которых дают одну из 3 ачивок. Советую поискать их самим, без подсказок - это того стоит.

Just buy it and give it a chance. I was pleasantly surprised and I'm willing to bet you will be too.

Dark Echo doesn't just rely on soundwaves to build it's world, it uses the imagination of the player themselves to fill in the details of this deep, dank and deadly cave. Drawing you in with atmospheric sound design the world around you begins to take shape, from a drop of water rhythmically falling from the ceiling to the deadly monsters lurking around every corner. The controls feel very tight, every single foot step has a weight to it. As the levels go on the game remains fresh, introducing new concepts and challenges at a fair and even pace. If I had one complaint it's that the elements of horror don't feel frantic enough, running away from monsters feels more like a jog through the mall than a life or death situation. Perhaps this is because the game wishes to be more of a puzzler than survival horror. Still loved that loud DEATH SCREAM though! There really is nothing else like Dark Echo, highly recommended!

PROS
-strong atmosphere
-smooth difficulty curve
-extremely unique mechanics

CONS
-monster encounters could be more intense


DISCLAIMER: Review is based on approx. 1 hour of gameplay.

Für alle, die ein etwas anderes Gameplay schätzen. 
Erstmal JA; es IST ein umgesetztes Touchscreen Spiel NA UND? Es gewinnt EXTREM auf dem PC

Das Spiel vermittelt tatsächlich eine Atmosphäre der Ungewissheit und der Furcht vor der Dunkelheit. 
Und das mit einfachsten Mitteln (Der Visualisierung von zurückprallenden Schallwellen) und der Zuhilfenahme von Farben (z.B. Rot für Gefahr bzw. für Angreifer oder Blau für Wasser).
Dazu die stimmige Geräuschkulisse, die einem Hinweise über das nicht zu Sehende gibt, und schon stapft man durch eine Dunkelheit, in dem die eigene Fantasie Gewölbe Untiere und Fallen vorgaukelt, obwohl doch nur farbige Linien zun sehen sind. Sollte man unbedingt im Dunkeln und vielleicht auch mit Kopfhörern spielen. Und das geht am PC ziemlich gut ab.  

 Und dann noch der farbliche Twist, wenn Hell zu Dunkel.... Hmm, selber rausfinden ;)  

Für diejenigen, die sich drauf einlassen können und die sich gerne mit einfachen Mitteln  in Atmosphäre ziehen lassen: eine tolle Erfahrung für wenig Geld. 

Für alle HD-Luxus-Grafik-Explosions-3D-Suchties und Bestzeit-Durchraser: knallt Euch das nächste AAA rein, und klickt weiter.

Sometimes you'll find doors, othertimes you'll be chased by a swarm of deadly red hate - and that's when my pulse started to quicken, but all you have to really do (insert evil laugh) is find the exit. Creative, unique and minimalist are the words that immediately come to mind.  I used to have old school 'Tetris' dreams of imagining pieces falling in my sleep when I'd played way too much. 16091169.review:
This game has an excellent idea behind it.

I haven't necessarily seen this type of game before, so I would say that it does have some originality. I'm sure there's someone out there who doubts its originality, or has seen it before, but I'm not one of those people. 

With that being said, I enjoyed the game for the time that I played it. I got all the way through the darkness, but I didn't go further than that. I think that at some point I will go back through and do the light levels, because I'm sure that there's something I might have missed. 


[h1]Meat of the review[/h1]
I don't necessarily go by a rating system whenever I review games. I consider: Is it reasonably priced for the level of enjoyment I got out of the gameplay? Does it have a unique quality about it that other games don't have? Will I ever be able to go back and replay the game? 

Those are three questions that I consider whenever I'm playing a game. Those are three fairly important questions to me as well. 

First question: With a price tag of $2.99, it is very affordable. Not only that, but I was riveted to the game and I was determined on finishing all of the levels, I won't spoil how many. If you want to know here's the number: [spoiler] 30 [/spoiler] Which I thought was a great amount of levels, and the variability of the levels was incredible. Not only is the game innovative, but the level design is complex and dynamic. The levels challenged my awareness and problem solving.  Of course, I think it is very reasonably priced for the level of enjoyment I got out of it. 

Second question: Dark Echo is a game where [spoiler] you are blind [/spoiler] and the object of the game is to find the exit using [spoiler] your sense of hearing.[/spoiler]  I found the game fascinating for this reason. This quality of the game gave the title of the game some depth. I thought that the nature of the game stuck to its title. The game is definitely unique in the respect of bringing gameplay to the table that hasn't been recycled over and over again. 

Third question: As far as replayability is concerned, I'm going with that I'm not sure if it does have replayability. For me I didn't necessarily play this game for very long, but for the amount of time I played it I think it justified the price tag. But the light levels are something that are worth looking into for people who are potentially looking at this game and aren't necessarily sure about it. 

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
Overall I think that the game is worth at least looking into. In all of my reviews, I tell everyone who gets this far to have a look at it. Don't take what I have to say and just go out and buy it. You should go look up videos, or look up other reviews. You and I might not have the same tastes as far as games are concerned. Enjoy Dark Echo!

16067020.review:
[b]First playthrough time: 7 hours[/b]

[b]Major Pros:[/b]
Excellent minimalist art style with a great use of colors
Good sound effects set mood and keep the player on edge (but aren't necessary for the game if they creep you out!)

[b]Minor Pros:[/b]
The second half of the game, the light world, lets the player replay the same level layouts with new traps, solutions, and more (and faster) monsters
Excellent level design allows players to learn what to do on their own without explanation and level names give hints

[b]Major Cons:[/b]
Angles to aim your character at in order to effectively throw rocks are limited to the 8 points of a compass

[b]Minor Cons:[/b]
Will leave you terrified of orb shaped patterns of red lines which others will not understand
You will also learn to hate water
I think I "fell" out of a level once or twice due to a moving block glitching me through a wall

I'm a sucker for a good art style and minimalist art styles like the one in Dark Echo with their high contrast and bright colors really appeal to me. Combine that with a unique puzzle experience that gives my mental visualization abilities a stretch and cheap price tag and I snagged this thing the day it came out. The following 7 hours of gameplay left my heart beating a little faster as I snuck, tricked, and bolted my way for the exit. I found all the levels to be interesting and fun except that one level at the end with too many moving parts where I died a lot and if you've played you know what I'm talking about. My biggest complaint about the game was just that your character is limited to only facing 8 different directions which makes creating effective distractions at the right place a little difficult sometimes. Given the simplicity of the controls however, the 8 direction limit seems appropriate. Overall I loved the game and hope to see many more like it in the future.

15985578.review:
Here is my 30Second Game Review on Dark echo: https://youtu.be/PjP5htKzZ10

This game is like being Daredevil in a psychological thriller. Sound is your only friend. Every noise you make bounces off the wall, making you “see” a minimalistic impression of your surroundings. The effects - mesmerizing. 

But you are not alone. You have to escape unknown creatures through mazes and puzzles. And when you make a noise, they notice you as well. So find a safe path, unlock doors and escape death.

Play it with headphones on and all alone in the dark and every step will be filled with tension.

Made of 80 levels with a cool horror atmosphere and a lot of originality.

Seven claps out of ten.

Was soll ich an diesem Spiel noch groß erklären? Man irrt durch dunkle/helle Gebiete (Räume? Höhlen? Katakomben?) und versucht, den Ausgang zu erreichen, ohne dass man auf rote .... ich sag jetzt mal Stacheln, tritt, oder von einem Verfolger erwischt wird. Wenn man Lärm macht, kann man sich besser orientieren, die Gegner finden einen dafür aber auch leichter bzw. schneller bzw. verdammt schnell. Zusätzlich gibt es noch gelbe Flächen, Schalter, und blaue Flächen, Wasser, das einem durch Unmengen an Lärm, wenn man darin schwimmt, das Leben schwer macht. 

Abgesehen von der etwas beschränkten Anzahl an Gegnern (Verfolger, "Todesringe", tödliche Flächen) hab ich nicht allzu viel zu kritisieren, da es trotzdem abwechslungsreich genug ist. Kein Spiel, das man in einem Satz durchspielt, eher was für zwischendurch. Es ist hauptsächlich ein Puzzle-Game, mit leichtem Horror-Feeling, Klaustrophobie und "Hilflosigkeit" als Bonus. Gut, die Level sind (relativ) kurz, das ist hier auch häufig kritisiert worden. Aber da ein Fehler das virtuelle Ende bedeutet, wäre es eher frustrierend, wenn sie länger wären. 40 dunkle und 40 helle Level (plus Geheimnisse) für 3€ bzw. (dank eines Sales) 2€ finde ich fair, es ist immerhin ein Casual-Game. Letztendlich kann ich es eigentlich jedem, der auf Puzzler steht, empfehlen. Fans von klassischem 3D-Horror eher weniger, ist eher was für Puristen. Ach ja, etwas hab ich noch vergessen, den Schwierigkeitsgrad: Die ersten 40 Level sind, abgesehen von vielleicht 2 bis 3 Ausnahmen eher leicht. In der zweiten Hälfte zieht der Schwierigkeitsgrad merklich an, wirklich schwierig sind aber "nur" die letzten 10 der 80 Level. Aber auch die sind zu schaffen. 

Ich hoffe, mein Review konnte euch helfen.  ;-)

15913695.review:
Dark Echo. Minimal und Maximal in einem.
Anhand der Geräusche, welche durch Streifen abgebildet werden, wandert man durch die Level. Anfangs nur leichtes zurecht finden. Klatschen, um mehr zu hörsehen. Dann die ersten Türen, verzweigtere Level, da, ein Gegner. Er ist schneller als ich selbst, trachtet nach mir, noch ein paar Schritte - der Ausgang ist erreicht. Das letzte Level noch lange nicht, größere folgen, mit mehr Überraschungen und höherem Schwierigkeitsgrad.

Minimal ist die Grafik, minimal das Gameplay, aber ein Maximum an Feeling stellt sich ein. Spannung, Neugier, Hektik, Furcht. Ich empfehle ebenfalls ein Spiel mit Kopfhörer und in einem möglichst dunklen Raum. Man hört nur schwer auf zu spielen. Spiel es.

Okay so lets be honest. This type of game is somewhat unique but isn't an original idea. It has been done before but not in this atmospheric horror fashion. Frankly I didn't feel the atmosphere that everyone talked about in the reviews. It was more annoying than anything. The game is trying to challenge you with certain aspects but it just ends up being boring (when you get to the stealth portions of the game you'll see what I mean).
   The horror factor isn't all that great either. The reason other indie horror games (Take FNAF for example) are actually scary is because they always keep you on your toes. You always know that there's a monster right outside your door and you have .25 seconds to react. In this game you only feel annoyed by the enemies; like their purpose is just to distract you from your goal, rather than trying to eat you.
   This game was a nice concept, the sound of footsteps to show paths combined with atmospheric horror, but it just didn't seem to live up to its potential. Now I feel like I've bought a game just for the achievements or collectibles, and that isn't how its supposed to be.

15851026.review:
Just a brief history. Dark Echo is a brilliant mobile game that managed it's way to Steam. The game is minimalistic at best and was created in a short 48 hours for Ludum Dare's Minimalism Contest eventually placing second place. Out of 1600 entries. This is a much more refined and improved version.

This game creates horror and suspense, being one of the most creepy games I've played so far, all while retaining it's simplicity.

The game starts  out by placing you in the footsteps of a blind person alone in the dark. It doesn't give you a clue where you are, what do you encounter and who are you. It is all up to your imagination.

See those red lines chasing you? You don't know who they are. Could be a monster, a zombie or maybe even a serial killer. It is all up to your imagination to find out.

The only clue left is the game's engaging soundtrack - dripping water, doors, creaking bridges, the growling of monsters - it all provides an engaging experience and feel to the game when you play it with headphones, which is recommended by the developers.

If you're one of those who get this through the App Store, I'd recommend getting this through Steam and consider $10 a non-optional donation; They deserve it.

15838623.review:
セール中に199円で購入。
ゲーム内容は、一寸先も見えない暗闇の中で音の反響を用いて、部屋の構造を把握しフロアを脱出するというものです。
ジャンルとしてはパズルに近いと思います。

プレイした感想としては、意外と緊張感のあるゲームだったということです。
一般のパズルゲームにおいては、失敗した場合は画面が暗転して最初からリスタートするものが大半で、
偶に、「failed」というような失敗を知らせるアナウンスが流れるというものがあるくらいです。

しかし、このDark Echoというゲームでは一味違った演出が用いられています。
この演出のおかげで、失敗したくないという気持ちが生まれ、それが焦りや緊張感に繋がります。
また、音響にも拘っていて、暗闇の中には何があるのかという想像を掻き立ててくれます。
もしプレイする際には、静かな部屋でヘッドフォンを付けてのプレイを是非お勧めしたいです。

欠点としては、ボリュームが少ないということです。一応30面ぐらいあるんですが、2時間で終わってしまいました。
また、ギミックのバリエーションが少ないので、複雑なギミックを解いていくのが好きな方には物足りなく感じるかもしれません。
後はチュートリアルが不親切で、操作方法が分かりにくかったため、以下に操作方法を記載しておきます。

＜操作方法＞
shift+移動キー（wasd）…静かに移動
スペースキー…その場で全方位に音を出す。押しっぱなしにした時間に応じて強さが変化。
ｚ+移動キー　…足跡の方向に合わせて石のようなものをなげ、ぶつかったところから全方位に音が広がる

まとめとして、多少の欠点はありますがパズルを解きながら雰囲気も楽しむことが出来たので個人的にはおすすめします。
もし興味があれば、購入して実際にプレイしてみてください！

15833286.review:
[table][tr][th][h1][b]FR[/b][/h1][/th][th][h1][u]Impressions[/u] : [/h1][/th][th] 🇨🇦  [/th][th]v. 1 -[/th][/tr][/table]/ 🇨🇦  / On a rarement l'opportunité d'aussi bien investir $2.00€ (oui, promo de lancement). Dark Echo vient de Vancouver (la Colombie Britannique). Il est le fruit du travail de 2 développeurs ayant une petite expérience tournée sur le mobile. 

Dark Echo offre un concept original que l'on manipule rarement : le son et sa propagation, bien sûr (ou malheureusement) vous n'interagissez pas au travers de l'acoustique mais de la représentation visuelle des « ondes ». Ondes qui ne se propagent pas comme une vaguelette à la surface de l'eau, mais comme des segments rectilignes tangent à leur source. 

Dark Echo est sympathique, la difficulté est longue à se mettre en train mais elle finit par débouler. Les obstacles sont assez variés : [list][*]trouver le chemin vers la sortie (c'est simple); [*]ouvrir l'œil et ne pas se prendre les pièges qui ne se révèlent qu'au dernier moment;[*]Ne pas attirer les entités qui réagissent aux bruits;[*]utiliser les mécanismes d'ouvertures de passages (qui émettent toujours du son); [*]se mouvoir à la bonne vitesse et emprunter les bonne trajectoire pour esquiver les dangers.[/list]
Vous pouvez marcher ou courir, l'un émet juste un peu moins de bruit que l'autre, il y a également des surfaces qui propagent le son différemment, ou encore passer sur des éléments qui émettent un bruit d'une nature différente (de l'eau).

C'est une expérience que je recommande, simple et novatrice. Cependant, il offre certaines imperfections forts tristes. Malgré sa brievté, il flirt un peu trop avec la repétitivité. Le design est typé mais trop peu varié (FOTONICA est un bel exemple de style minimaliste et peu varié qui pourtant domine très bien ce problème).  Sur mobile, ça doit être du plus bel effet, mais après plusieurs minutes a tâtonner pour trouver sa voie, la réussite d'un niveau se solde par un violent flash blanc sur la totalité de l'écran. Ce qui brûle votre rétine habituée à une clarté moindre...
Les bruits de pas bouclent sur un seul son (ou pas beaucoup plus)...

Finalement, je pense qu'avec un tel concept les développeurs auraient du aller plus loin (mais il n'est pas trop tard), une génération procédurale serait parfaite — vous ne verrez jamais tout une carte mais après être mort 3 fois vous savez comment éviter les difficultés. Créer ses propres niveaux via un Workshop, se concentrer un peu plus sur l'aspect labyrinthique et sur les pièges naturels...

Avec Dark Echo, j'ai envie de penser : « Ce n'est qu'un aurevoir ? »[quote][h1]N'hésitez pas à réagir, que ce soit pour une question ou pour signaler une erreur[/h1][/quote] [table][tr][th]- -[/th][th][url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/smithfield]Smithfield[/url][/th][th][url=http://steamcommunity.com/discussions/forum/12/617328967244490669/][h1]Ajoutez-moi, si…![/h1][/url][/th][th][url=http://steamcommunity.com/discussions/forum/12/617329150699182932/][h1]Critiques:Les règles[/h1][/url][/th][/tr][/table]

15833133.review:
В это стоит сыграть в наушниках.
Минусы – Ну прежде всего это игра не для всех. Это не минус, но вполне возможно, что это стоит считать недостатком. Не все примут этот проект. Кому-то он покажется глупым и «очередной индюшкой». Я предупредил Вас. Ну а настоящим минусом игры, я считаю её малое разнообразие. В игре 50 (!) уровней. И если первую половину или даже первую двадцатку игра преподносит всё новые и новые условия выживания в этом мире звуков, то позже нововведения пропадают, и она (игра) начинает понемногу тяготить. Ждёшь поскорей титров. Это вовсе не значит, что я жалуюсь на её продолжительность. Тут ей в укор я ставлю именно то, что она исчерпывает себя ближе к середине. Это неслишком хорошо.
Плюсы – Играйте в наушниках. Правда, оно того стоит. Звук хороший, но музыки конечно же не ждите. Графика достаточно абстракта, но в этом и заключается весь её шарм. На чём особо хочу заострить своё внимание так это на игровом процессе и сюжете. Игровой процесс с одной стороны до неприличия простой, но в то же время достаточно продуман. Стелс-хоррор в чистом виде! Отвлекайте врагов, обходите ловушки, крадитесь, убегайте, взаимодействуйте с выключателями – всё просто. Что же насчёт сюжета? Ну в общем-то… его нет)) Каждый уровень носит своё название (кроме последнего, кажется), но в игре нет ни диалогов, ни брифингов, ни дневников. В игре кроме меню и названия уровней текста нет вовсе! Как Вы можете догадаться, взглянув на графический стиль игры, каких-либо чётких образов в игре тоже нет. Но как раз таки эти образы – пусть и до ужаса смутные и абстрактные – и подают весь сюжет. Вы смотрите на эти красные враждебные сгустки, летящие к Вам, и уже в своём воображении сами дорисовывайте монстра. Есть даже огромная матка! А читая, названия уровней уже даже придумываешь примерный набросок сюжета для уровня. Например уровень «Катакомбы» явно происходит под землёй, и я представлял, как мой персонаж бегает по подземным тоннелям в поисках лестницы наверх. В принципе, большинство странных игр рассчитано на людей, имеющих хорошую фантазию и отменное воображение. Те же говорящие голуби в одной визуальной новелле. Тот же симулятор хлеба. Но вот много ли игр тренирует Ваше воображение? Dark Echo – одна из них. Почти забыл – игра предусматривает некое подобие «Новой игры+» после прохождения. Повышается уровень сложности и меняется визуальное оформление.
Итог - Если Вы тот счастливчик, кому такая игра понравится, у кого всё в порядке с фантазией, то Вы оцените её по достоинству. То есть, она либо не нравится совсем, либо Вы угадали с покупкой. Чего-то среднего нет. Даже если Вам она вдруг наскучит, и Вы решите её забросить, то о покупке не пожалеете, я уверен.

15832761.review:
I want to like this game but I don't find its ambiance or gameplay engaging at all. It feels like a flash or mobile game in the sense that each level is a short path to victory with a tiny variation on the same theme. This is not a bad thing in and of itself but a game that relies on atmosphere should not present you with a transparent series of easy puzzles and little else.

I appreciate the game's clever design but I don't enjoy the gameplay. It didn't feel particularly scary, either: Red blobs make spooky ghost sounds and if you touch them they will eat you and restart the level. That is the sum of this game's horror elements. They will chase you if they hear you but they are stupendously easy to avoid. Holding shift makes you invisible to them and you can throw rocks to draw their attention away from you on a whim. 

Some of the levels make interesting use of the game's premise but most felt tedious.

What I liked:
Clever concept, some levels were intriguing, perceiving your environment requires effort

What I didn't like:
Lack of tension, mobile game level design, one-note enemies, lack of meaningful variation

진짜 미로같이 복잡한 맵(38스테이지)과 움직이는 벽이 있는 맵(39스테이지 등)만 빼고는 그렇게 어렵지 않아서 무난하게 올클리어는 할 수 있다.
그런데 게임을 하면서 도전과제용 보물은 하나도 못 모은것 같은데... 보물 모으려고 하다보면 난이도와 플탐 모두 급증할 듯. 

물웅덩이에서의 팁이 하나 있는데, 앞으로 살짝 걸어가면서 돌 던지고, 다시 앞으로 살짝 가면서 돌 던지는 걸 타이밍에 맞게 반복하면 발자국 소리 없이 건널 수 있다.

"Приятный визуальный минимализм"

Короткая и простенькая головоломка-лабиринт с одной отличительной особенностью - главный герой слеп (или же он просто в полной темноте, как вам нравится). В некоторых локациях геометрия отражения звука напоминает простенький зрительный образ как в проигрывателе винды.
Такой визульный минимализм придает игре свой шарм, однако яростно рекомендовать её я не буду. Это просто хорошая игрушка. В пределах своей ценовой категории, кстати.

39886068.review:
[h1]类型[/h1]
关卡类探索

[h1]游戏方法[/h1]
通过走动、跺脚、投石发出声音，声波的传播方向被具象化，可以通过它的反射判断环境地形，找到出口。同时要注意避免会被声音吸引的怪物将你撕成碎片。

[h1]感想[/h1]
游戏里面主要设置了安全地带、触发开门机关地带、死亡地带、可被震动激活地带、水域、俯视遮挡、伸缩墙等几种区域，还有会循声而来的怪兽。游戏采用关卡式，让玩家运用声波的反馈找到出口完成游戏。
优点在于题材新颖，整个游戏画面非常简洁，如果驻足不前，画面上将只会剩下玩家的双足标记，只有通过走动、跺脚或是投石发出声音时，才能判断周边地形。
缺点在于关卡过多，而游戏变化不足，玩起来比较单调。

39743480.review:
[h1] Dark Echo	[/h1]
Мы - странник, попавший в таинственный особняк. Но как же выбраться из кромешной темноты? По звукам! Встретятся ли враги? О, да!
У игры очень интересная задумка: при ходьбе звук отражается от стен, что позволяет ориентироваться в пространстве.
Звуки, скрипы, топот создают гнетущую атмосферу. Атмосферу одиночества и тревожности.
Картинка работает на контрасте чёрного и белого, а также ярких синего и красного цветов. Смотрится здорово.

Из минусов отмечу продолжительность. Основная игра проходится за 1,5 часа, а также есть «светлая» сторона, она на порядок сложнее, занимает примерно 2,5 часа.
Хотя с другой стороны, в игру не хочется возвращаться.

В итоге получаем не больше, чем неплохую мобильную игру на пару вечеров с действительно хорошей задумкой, но низкой реиграбельностью. За 15 рублей по скидке самое оно.

[h1] Оценка: 6,5 / 10	[/h1]

Найди выход!
